abstracts.cdata!:
Overall project outcome is rated
            partially satisfactory with specific components rated as
            follows: the credit line, technical assistance, and
            regulation components were related as partially satisfactory
            while the privatization component was rated as highly
            satisfactory. Key lessons learned were: The World
            Bank's response to new priorities in a changing policy
            environment can make possible achievements greater than had
            been originally anticipated. However, this response does
            come at a cost and can increase project complexity, which
            can strain supervision resources. Another cost, especially
            in supporting new institutions, is delayed implementation.
            Because institution building is a long and sometimes complex
            process, delays should not be seen as evidence of
            implementation failure per se where a project is achieving
            substantive institutional change. Directed lines of credit
            focusing specifically, for example, on small and medium
            enterprises are unduly restrictive and do not necessarily
            encourage participating financial intermediaries (PFIs) to
            develop business in this area. Limited interventions in
            institution-building projects are acceptable only if they
            form one part of a larger program. Where there are no clear
            best practices, as was the case with the technical
            assistance component, special attention should be given to
            establishing monitoring and evaluation systems. A pilot
            approach that allows for experimentation is recommended.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is directed at facilitating
            the supply response to the economic adjustment efforts
            undertaken during the last four years.  It will focus on the
            private manufacturing sector, providing financial and
            technical assistance to private manufacturing firms.  It
            will also support improvements in the regulatory environment
            and strengthen key institutions in the sector. The
            project's objectives include : a) increasing private
            industry's contribution to production, employment
            creation, and exports, by facilitating access to longer term
            working capital; b) providing technical managerial
            assistance to private firms in order to improve their
            productivity; c) assisting in improving the quality of
            services provided by public and private sector institutions;
            and d) simplifying the regulatory framework affecting the
            establishment of new businesses.  To achieve the above, the
            project will consist of the following components : 1) US$14
            million to finance the needs of private manufacturing firms
            in fixed assets, working capital, and subproject related
            technical and managerial expenditures and 2) a technical
            assistance component of up to US$2 million to finance
            technical assistance activities in support of private sector
            beneficiaries and the Central Bank, strengthening of
            particpating private and public institutions, and studies in
            support of private sector development.
